questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bag & Mask ventilation 

 

  • In a neonate presenting with a scaphoid abdomen, certain respiratory interventions need to be carefully considered due to the high risk of underlying conditions like congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). 

 

This is contraindicated in neonates with a scaphoid abdomen suspected of having CDH. The use of positive pressure from bag and mask ventilation can exacerbate the displacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through the diaphragmatic defect, potentially worsening respiratory distress and leading to further compromise of pulmonary function. This method of ventilation can increase the risk of pneumothorax, gastric distention, and further reduce lung volume, which is already compromised in CDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation): Like intubation, IPPV is used via a mechanical ventilator after intubation and can provide controlled and safe respiratory support. It is also appropriate in these scenarios to ensure that airway pressure is managed carefully to avoid exacerbating the hernia.

 

Option C. Intubation: This is the preferred method for securing the airway in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen when CDH is suspected. Intubation allows for controlled ventilation settings, minimizes gastric distension, and helps manage the baby’s respiratory status more effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The critical point in managing a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen, particularly when a condition like CDH is suspected, involves avoiding exacerbation of the hernia through inappropriate respiratory support techniques. Opting for intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation instead of bag & mask ventilation is crucial to prevent further complications and stabilize the infant's condition. Properly securing the airway and ensuring adequate ventilation without increasing the risk of further pulmonary or gastrointestinal injury is essential in the initial management of these patients.

choices.text: TACE is used for multinodular lesions
Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm
The incidence of HCC is increasing
NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC

questions.text: Identify the false statement out of the following: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

 

Lenvatinib is used to treat advanced stages of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Treatment of lesions less than 3 cm is wide excision or liver transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TACE is used for multinodular lesions: True. TACE (Transarterial chemoembolization) combined with other treatments is used for unresectable multiple nodular and massive HCC, especially when a single nodular diameter is greater than 5 cm (intermediate or advanced HCC).

 

Option C. The incidence of HCC is increasing: True. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide due to the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity.

 

Option D. NASH (Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis) and NAFLD (Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease) are risk factors for HCC: True. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NALD), which progresses to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC.
  • Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.
  • Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs.
  • Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the otolaryngology clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the parotid gland, which is located in the cheek area. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. The physician ordered an ultrasound imaging of the salivary glands, which revealed the presence of multiple hyper-echoic areas within the parotid gland. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

  • Sialolithiasis is a condition where a stone or calculus forms within a salivary gland or duct.
  • This condition is most commonly found in the submandibular gland but can also occur in the parotid gland and other salivary glands.
  • Sialolithiasis can cause symptoms such as pain, swelling, and tenderness in the affected gland, difficulty opening the mouth, and dry mouth, especially during eating when salivary secretion increases (known as Meal time syndrome).
  • The stones themselves can sometimes be palpated and can be seen on imaging studies like ultrasound, which might display hyper-echoic (darker) areas representing the stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foreign body: A foreign body in the context of the parotid gland could refer to any external object that has somehow made its way into the gland or its duct. It's an uncommon occurrence for a foreign body to be located in the salivary glands. Typically, if someone were to suspect a foreign body, there would likely be a history of trauma or an incident where the foreign object could have entered the gland.

 

Option C. Osteoma of the floor of the mouth: Osteoma is a benign bone tumor. An osteoma of the floor of the mouth would represent an abnormal growth of bone within that specific region. It wouldn't typically be a cause of parotid gland swelling or discomfort. Moreover, osteomas are more radiopaque and wouldn't typically present as hyper-echoic areas on an ultrasound.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes in the cervical (neck) region. Enlarged lymph nodes can be due to various causes, including infections, inflammatory conditions, or malignancies. While they can be present near the parotid gland, they are distinct from it. Swelling of the lymph nodes wouldn't typically cause pain that worsens during eating, as described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Given the symptoms described, especially the pain that worsens with eating, and the ultrasound findings, Sialolithiasis (option A) is the most likely diagnosis for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sialolithiasis, characterized by the formation of calculi in the salivary glands, typically presents with pain and swelling, especially during meals.
  • Ultrasound imaging can identify hyper-echoic areas representing the stones, helping in the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C) Insulinoma. These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • It is associated with the overproduction of gastrin, which leads to excessive stomach acid production.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

 

Option D. VIPoma:

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2V3M4

 

The GCS score of this patient is E2V3M4

 

  • Opening eves to a painful stimulus - E2
  • Speak inappropriately - V3
  • Withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus - M4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is an essential tool for assessing the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury.
  • It involves evaluating the eye opening response, verbal response, and motor response, with scores ranging from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).
  •  Understanding how to correctly assess and calculate the GCS score is crucial for determining the severity of the injury and guiding appropriate medical intervention.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency following a car accident. His Blood Pressure is 90/60 mm of Hg, His Glasgow coma scale is 9. He has suffered injuries to the abdominal viscera. The least likely cause of hypovolemia in this patient is? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural hematoma

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH) involves bleeding between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater, typically from venous sources such as the bridging veins. While SDH is a significant and serious condition, it generally does not lead to hypovolemia because the bleeding is contained within the intracranial space and does not result in large-volume blood loss.

 

  • Source: Bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma (acceleration, deceleration force)
  • Radiological Findings: Concavo-convex hyperdensity on NCCT Head
  • Patient Profile: Usually seen in elderly or obese individuals after a fall

 

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Splenic Injury:
    • The spleen is one of the most commonly injured organs in blunt abdominal trauma. Injury or rupture of the spleen can result in significant internal bleeding and hypovolemia.
    • Features: Can cause substantial internal bleeding leading to hypovolemia.
  • Option C. Retroperitoneal Hematoma:
    • The retroperitoneal space contains several large blood vessels, including the aorta and inferior vena cava. Injuries to these vessels or other structures in this space can result in large-volume blood loss into the retroperitoneal space, leading to hypovolemia.
    • Features: Significant blood loss into retroperitoneal space, causing hypovolemia.
  • Option D. Hemothorax:
    • Hemothorax is the collection of blood in the pleural cavity, which can occur due to traumatic injuries. Traumatic hemothorax can result in significant blood loss, leading to hypovolemia.
    • Features: Blood accumulation in pleural cavity, causing hypovolemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subdural hematoma, characterized by bleeding between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater, is least likely to cause hypovolemia compared to splenic injury, retroperitoneal hematoma, or hemothorax

choices.text: Pain occurs on walking a fixed distance and is relieved by rest
Pain occurs immediately on standing and improves on bending forward
Pain is worse at night in bed and at rest
Pain occurs on taking the first step

questions.text: Which of these is true about intermittent claudication? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain occurs on walking a fixed distance and is relieved by rest

 

Intermittent claudication characteristics:

 

  • Pain occurs after walking a predictable distance
  • Distance is relatively fixed for each patient
  • Pain is relieved by rest within minutes
  • Indicates chronic peripheral arterial disease
  • Due to inadequate blood flow during exercise

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pain occurs immediately on standing and improves on bending forward:

 

  • This describes neurogenic claudication
  • Characteristic of lumbar canal stenosis
  • Not related to vascular insufficiency

 

Option C. Pain is worse at night in bed and at rest:

 

  • This describes rest pain
  • Feature of critical limb ischemia
  • Advanced stage of peripheral arterial disease
  • Not intermittent claudication

 

Option D. Pain occurs on taking the first step:

 

  • Feature of neurogenic claudication
  • Seen in spinal canal stenosis
  • Not characteristic of vascular disease

 

Educational Objective: 


Intermittent claudication is characterized by pain occurring after walking a fixed distance and being relieved by rest, similar to angina of the legs.

choices.text: Typically presents between postoperative days 3 and 5
Suture length should be 4 times the wound length
High incidence if Catgut is used for closure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Burst Abdomen is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Typically presents between postoperative days 3 and 5

 

Explanation:

 

Burst abdomen (abdominal wound dehiscence) usually occurs after 5-7 days post-laparotomy. This directly contradicts option B, which incorrectly states it typically presents between days 3-5. The condition is characterized by the "salmon fluid sign" where large quantities of serous fluid come out from the wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence is 1-3 percent - This represents an accurate statistical range for the occurrence of burst abdomen following laparotomy procedures.

 

Option C. Suture length should be 4 times the wound length - This is a correct technical specification for proper abdominal wall closure to prevent dehiscence, also known as Jenkin’s rule.

 

Option D. High incidence if Catgut is used for closure - This is accurate because catgut is an absorbable suture material associated with higher rates of wound failure compared to more modern synthetic materials.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burst abdomen is a serious post-operative complication that presents with the salmon fluid sign typically 5-7 days after surgery, requiring emergency management with a Bogota bag laparostomy followed by definitive re-suturing of the abdominal wall.

questions.text: Decubitus ulcer is best classified as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Pressure ulcer

 

Explanation:

 

Decubitus ulcer is synonymous with pressure ulcer. These terms describe tissue necrosis with ulceration resulting from prolonged pressure that exceeds capillary occlusion pressure (over 30mmHg), leading to tissue anoxia and breakdown. They occur in areas where bony prominences create sustained pressure against soft tissues, particularly in bedridden or immobile patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous ulcer - Venous ulcers have distinct characteristics, typically appearing above the medial malleolus in the "Gaiter's area." They present as shallow ulcers associated with other signs of venous insufficiency such as hyperpigmentation, dermatitis, and varicosities. Unlike decubitus ulcers, they result from venous hypertension rather than direct pressure.

 

Option B. Arterial ulcer - Arterial (ischemic) ulcers occur at distal locations like toes and dorsum of foot. They are characteristically deep, severely painful, and associated with signs of peripheral vascular disease including brittle nails, sparse hair, and intermittent claudication. They stem from inadequate arterial perfusion rather than external pressure.

 

Option C. Neuropathic ulcer - Neuropathic ulcers typically form on weight-bearing areas of the foot with characteristic "punched out" edges and surrounding callosity. They develop due to sensory, motor, and autonomic neuropathy (commonly in diabetic patients) rather than from external pressure. The painless nature of these ulcers distinguishes them from decubitus ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pressure sores (decubitus ulcers) result from sustained pressure exceeding tissue perfusion pressure, causing ischemia and necrosis predominantly at bony prominences like the ischium, greater trochanter, and sacrum in immobile patients.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from height. The patient reports no pain or injury, but on examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. The patient is hemodynamically stable with no other injuries. The next step in management would be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ascending urethrogram

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests a suspected urethral injury with blood at the urethral meatus, which is commonly caused by external trauma or instrumentation.
  •  To confirm urethral rupture, the next step would be an ascending urethrogram.
  • Ascending urethrogram: Correct. In a patient who is hemodynamically stable and without symptoms of a full bladder, retrograde urethrography will help determine the extent of the injury and decide on the next appropriate steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheterization: In the setting of suspected urethral injury, as evidenced by the presence of blood at the tip of the urethral meatus, inserting a Foley catheter can be harmful. It could potentially exacerbate the injury or convert a partial tear into a complete one. Hence, this is contraindicated without first confirming the integrity of the urethra.

 

Option C. Nephrogram: A nephrogram is an imaging study of the kidneys and their function. While it can give details about the upper urinary tract, it's not typically used for evaluating urethral injuries.

 

Option D. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy, or suprapubic catheter placement, involves inserting a catheter directly into the bladder through the abdominal wall. It's done to divert urine when urethral catheterization is not possible or contraindicated, such as in the setting of a known or suspected urethral injury. This will be attempted after an urethrogram confirms a rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management.
  • Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.

questions.text: Which appendicular carcinoma is most commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritoneii? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucinous adenocarcinoma 

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a rare condition characterized by the presence of mucinous ascites due to the dissemination of mucus-producing cells within the peritoneal cavity.

 

This is a type of cancer that arises from cells that produce mucus, commonly from the appendix. It is the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei, as these malignant cells can spread throughout the peritoneal cavity and secrete mucin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucinous cystadenoma: This is a benign ovarian tumor that can produce mucus, but it is less commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei compared to its malignant counterparts.

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that can occur in the appendix. While they can spread, they are not typically associated with the production of abundant mucin that characterizes pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: This is a benign tumor that can occur in the ovaries and produce a watery serous fluid, not the mucinous ascites seen in pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mucinous adenocarcinoma, particularly of the appendix, is the most common appendicular carcinoma associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei, characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-functioning adenoma

 

Most frequent cause of adrenal incidentaloma is Non-functioning adenoma

 

An adrenal incidentaloma is an unexpected adrenal mass detected on imaging not performed for suspected adrenal disease.

 

Non-functioning adrenal adenomas do not secrete hormones in significant amounts to cause clinical syndromes. They are benign tumors that are often discovered incidentally on imaging studies. Histologically, they are similar to hormone-secreting adenomas, but they do not produce clinical symptoms or biochemical abnormalities. They are the most common type of adrenal incidentaloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical Cushing's syndrome: Subclinical Cushing's syndrome refers to the mild or asymptomatic cortisol excess from an adrenal adenoma. These patients lack the full-blown signs and symptoms of overt Cushing's syndrome but might show subtle manifestations of cortisol excess or have abnormal laboratory findings.

 

Option B. Aldosterone producing adenoma: Aldosterone producing adenomas are a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism. They produce excess aldosterone leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. Patients may have suppressed renin levels in the blood due to feedback inhibition from the elevated aldosterone.

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytomas are tumors of the adrenal medulla that produce excessive amounts of catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine). Symptoms often include paroxysms of hypertension, headache, sweating, and palpitations. While these are serious tumors, they are a less common cause of adrenal incidentalomas.

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neck

 

Explanation:

 

The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.

 

Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

questions.text: The sequence of color change in Raynaud’s disease: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) White - Blue - Red

 

Explanation:

 

Raynaud's disease follows a characteristic sequence of color changes in the digits. The phenomenon shows a typical pattern: first, the digits turn white (pallor/syncope) due to arteriolar constriction; then they become blue/cyanotic (asphyxia) as capillaries dilate and fill with deoxygenated blood; finally, they turn red (reactive hyperemia) when arterioles relax and oxygenated blood returns to the dilated capillaries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Red - Blue - White This sequence is incorrect. The initial phase of Raynaud's is vasoconstriction causing pallor (white), not redness. The arterial supply is initially shut down, not increased.

 

Option C. White - Red - Blue This sequence is incorrect. After the initial white phase, blood stagnates in the capillaries leading to cyanosis (blue), not redness. Red is the final recovery phase.

 

Option D. Red - White - Blue This is the complete reverse of the correct sequence and physiologically impossible in Raynaud's disease. The condition begins with vasoconstriction (white), not vasodilation (red).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Raynaud's disease manifests with a pathognomonic triple-color change sequence (white-blue-red) corresponding to the pathophysiological stages of vasospasm: initial vasoconstriction (pallor), followed by capillary dilatation with deoxygenated blood (cyanosis), and finally arteriolar relaxation with return of oxygenated blood (erythema).

questions.text: Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ERCP and Bile duct

 

The abdominal X-ray KUB image shows a stent, specifically a double J (DJ) stent, commonly used in surgeries. The appearance and orientation of the stent are key to identifying its location. In this case, the stent is positioned vertically, which indicates it is in the bile duct. The bile duct runs vertically in the body, and a biliary stent used in procedures like ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) would also be oriented vertically. Conversely, a stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally due to the anatomical layout of the pancreatic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ERCP and Pancreatic duct: A stent in the pancreatic duct would be oriented horizontally, not vertically, due to the horizontal course of the pancreatic duct. The given image shows a vertically oriented stent, which rules out this option.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic balloon catheter: This type of catheter would have a different appearance and is not typically placed in a vertical orientation like the stent shown in the X-ray.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous catheter: This type of catheter is used for different purposes and would not appear as a vertical stent in the abdominal X-ray. It also wouldn't be located in the bile duct or pancreatic duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vertical orientation of a stent on an abdominal X-ray is indicative of its placement in the bile duct, particularly in procedures involving ERCP.

questions.text: Imaging modality of choice for fistula in Ano is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRI

 

Fistula-in-ano is an abnormal tract that communicates between the inner surface of the anal canal and the outer skin. The main concern with this condition is the recurrence after treatment, making accurate mapping of the fistulous tract essential.

 

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is the gold standard for imaging fistula-in-ano. It provides high-resolution images that can accurately detail the course, depth, and branches of a fistulous tract. MRI can also differentiate between active and inactive tracts, identify secondary extensions, and help in delineating the relationship of the fistula with the sphincter muscles. This makes it invaluable for both diagnosis and preoperative planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PET-CT: PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography) is an imaging modality that is primarily used for detecting and monitoring the progression or regression of cancers.

 

Option C. Sinogram: A sinogram involves injecting contrast into the external opening of a fistula to delineate its course and internal opening on radiographs. While it can provide information about the fistula's course, it may not provide comprehensive information about secondary tracts, the condition of the surrounding tissues, or the relationship with the sphincter muscles.

 

Option D. CT: CT (Computed Tomography) can provide a detailed image of the anatomy and can be used to identify fistula-in-ano. However, it may not be as sensitive or detailed as MRI, especially when it comes to evaluating the small intricacies of the fistula tract or its relationship with the sphincter complex.

 

Fistulae are classified according to Park’s classification.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The imaging modality of choice for evaluating fistula-in-ano is MRI due to its high-resolution imaging capabilities, which provide detailed information about the course, depth, branches of the fistula tract, and its relationship with surrounding structures.

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

 

14 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 14 Fr are commonly used in adult female patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Fr: 6 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 6 Fr are commonly used in pediatric patients or in adults with narrow urethras. They are also used in urodynamic studies to measure bladder pressures.

 

Option C. 16 Fr: 16 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 16 Fr are commonly used in adult male patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Option D. 22 Fr: 22 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 22 Fr are commonly used in patients for suprapubic cystostomy. They are also used in patients who have undergone prostate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FOLEY’S CATHETER

 

The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3rd mm.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice has a distended gall bladder and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound. Which of the following will be most useful to localize the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

Given scenario of an elderly male with obstructive jaundice and distended gall bladder, is suggestive of periampullary tumour. The best investigation would be a CECT abdomen (not provided in the option) or MRCP.

 

Correct. MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that visualizes the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It provides detailed images without the need for ionizing radiation or invasive procedures. Given the patient's age and presentation, MRCP is an ideal choice to visualize obstructions or abnormalities in the bile duct system without posing additional risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This is a useful modality for visualizing the biliary tree, pancreas, and surrounding structures. It can be particularly helpful in assessing small lesions or stones that might be missed by other imaging modalities. It would be utilised if MRCP/CECT did not yield adequate diagnosis, or for staging of periampullary tumors.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography: This is an invasive procedure where contrast is injected directly into the biliary system through the liver, and then X-rays are taken. It can be diagnostic as well as therapeutic (e.g., for bile duct drainage). However, it's more invasive than MRCP and might not be the first choice for solely diagnostic purposes in a 72-year-old patient.

 

Option D. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It involves inserting an endoscope through the mouth to the duodenum and injecting contrast into the bile and pancreatic ducts. While ERCP can visualize and treat obstructions, it's invasive and carries risks like pancreatitis, especially if used primarily for diagnostic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive jaundice is a condition in which there is a blockage of the flow of bile out of the liver. This results in redirection of excess bile and its by-products into the blood, and bile excretion from the body is incomplete

 

Symptoms of obstructive jaundice include yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes; paler stools and darker urine; and intense itching.

 

The most common cause of obstructive jaundice is the presence of CBD stones (choledocholithiasis). Other causes of obstructive jaundice are tumors, trauma, cysts, and inflammation in the bile ducts.

questions.text: A Patient after head trauma is opening eyes to verbal commands, localizing pain and is confused. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12

Explanation:

Glasgow Coma Scale calculation:

Eye Opening (E): Opening to verbal commands = 3 points

Motor Response (M): Localizing pain = 5 points

Verbal Response (V): Confused = 4 points

Total GCS = E(3) + M(5) + V(4) = 12 points

Educational Objective:

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

questions.text: A 35-year-old car racer is brought to the emergency department after a car accident on the race track. He is unconscious and is immediately put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

 

His GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6.

 

Eye-opening to verbal command - 3

 

Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6

 

In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT.

 

Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

questions.text: A patient has undergone laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the structure as marked? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic artery

 

The image provided shows an intraoperative view during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, focusing on the Calot's triangle. This area is critical for identifying key anatomical structures to safely remove the gallbladder.

 

Calot's triangle is bordered by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior border of the liver. The "critical view of safety" is a surgical technique used to clearly identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct before clipping and cutting them.

 

In the image, the marked structure is the inner one, closer to the liver. This inner structure is the cystic artery. The outer structure, which is away from the liver and entering the gallbladder, is the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic duct: The cystic duct is the tube that connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. In the image, it is the outer structure marked CD, which is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option C. Right hepatic artery: This artery supplies blood to the right lobe of the liver and is not typically involved in the structures identified within Calot's triangle during a cholecystectomy.

 

Option D. Hepatic duct: The hepatic duct is part of the biliary duct system, joining with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct. It is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, it is crucial to identify the cystic artery and the cystic duct within Calot's triangle to prevent injury to the biliary structures and ensure a safe surgical procedure.

questions.text: A chronic smoker starts having pain in the calf on walking a distance of 400 meters. Gradually he starts developing pain on walking a distance of as less as 200 meters only. Currently he even gets pain in his calf while lying down. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rest pain

 

History of a chronic smoker with intermittent claudication followed by continuous calf pain even at rest is indicative of Rest Pain. This is seen in Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Diseases (PAD) like Buerger’s disease or atherosclerosis. Rest pain is typically experienced in the feet or toes and can be so severe that it awakens the patient from sleep. Chronic smoking is a significant risk factor for PAD.

 

The progression of symptoms described – from pain with walking decreasing distances to pain even while at rest – fits the pattern of advancing PAD and critical limb ischemia. This patient's history of chronic smoking further aligns with the likelihood of PAD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous claudication:

 

  • Definition: Pain in the limbs due to venous insufficiency, which is caused by problems with the valves in the veins or venous hypertension.
  • Pain Characteristics: In venous claudication, pain typically gets worse on prolonged standing.
  • Suitability: The patient's pain occurs even at rest and while lying down, which is not characteristic of venous claudication.

 

Option B. Neurological claudication:

 

  • Definition: Pain that results from nerve compression, often due to lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • Pain Characteristics: The pain tends to be aggravated by standing or walking and is relieved by sitting or leaning forward.
  • Suitability: The pain from neurological claudication wouldn't typically manifest when the patient is lying down, as described in the scenario. Further, it begins immediately on walking.

 

Option C. Sciatica:

 

  • Definition: Pain radiating down the leg from the lower back, typically due to a herniated disc pressing on a nerve.
  • Pain Characteristics: The pain is often sharp and can be accompanied by numbness or tingling.
  • Suitability: Sciatica doesn't fit the pattern of pain that worsens with specific walking distances and occurs at rest, as described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rest pain in the context of chronic smoking and intermittent claudication progression indicates Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Disease (PAD).

questions.text: Lucid Interval is seen in? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extradural hematoma

 

Lucid interval refers to a period of consciousness that occurs between two periods of unconsciousness. This phenomenon is most commonly associated with Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH). In EDH, a traumatic injury causes bleeding between the skull and dura mater, usually from an arterial source like the Middle Meningeal Artery. This condition has a rapid onset, and patients often experience a transient loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval, and then a subsequent deterioration as the hematoma expands and increases intracranial pressure.

 

  • Origin: Arterial (Middle Meningeal Artery)
  • Features: Rapid onset, lucid interval seen
  • Radiological Findings: Lens-shaped, biconvex hyperdensity on CT scan that does not cross suture lines

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B. Subdural hematoma:
    • Subdural Hematoma (SDH) involves bleeding between the dura mater and arachnoid mater, typically from venous sources such as the emissary veins. SDH usually presents with a more gradual onset of symptoms and does not typically feature a lucid interval.
    • Radiological Findings: Crescent-shaped hyperdensity on CT scan that crosses suture lines.
  • Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
    • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) occurs due to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, often from a ruptured aneurysm. The classic presentation is a sudden, severe headache described as "the worst headache of my life." There is no lucid interval associated with SAH.
    • Radiological Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities on CT scan.
  • Option D. Scalp hematoma:
    • Scalp hematomas are collections of blood within the layers of the scalp due to trauma. These do not involve intracranial bleeding and do not present with a lucid interval. They are generally localized and less severe.
    • Radiological Findings: Localized soft tissue swelling without intracranial involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lucid interval is a key clinical feature of Extradural Hematoma, characterized by a transient period of consciousness following initial unconsciousness due to traumatic arterial bleeding between the skull and dura mater.

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

When the surgeon returns the entire hernial sac to the abdominal cavity without reducing its contents, this procedure is known as "reduction en masse" of the hernia.

 

Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a hernial sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Double loop of intestine is within a hernia sac with a tight neck.

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Organs like cecum (right) and sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and are present outside the sac.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia (irreducible).

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

After breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended. Radiotherapy has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of local recurrence after BCS for DCIS. In this patient, despite having a 7 mm margin clearance, the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS warrants the use of adjuvant radiotherapy to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is primarily used for invasive breast cancers, especially when there is a high risk of systemic spread. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and hence systemic chemotherapy is not typically indicated.

 

Option C. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up: Regular follow-up is crucial for any patient who has undergone treatment for breast cancer, but it is not the primary management strategy immediately after surgery for high nuclear grade DCIS.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used for HER2-positive invasive breast cancers. DCIS that is HER2-positive does not typically receive trastuzumab therapy, as the benefits of such treatment in non-invasive cancer have not been clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.

 

The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.

 

 

Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone

 

7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

10 to 12: Mastectomy

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower limb wound as shown. The wound had healthy granulation tissue. What will be used as a cover? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Split thickness skin graft

 

The correct answer is Split thickness skin graft (STSG). STSG is the preferred choice for covering a large, healing wound with healthy granulation tissue, such as a burn or degloving injury. It involves taking a thin layer of skin from a donor site and applying it to the wound. This type of graft covers large areas and is effective in promoting wound healing with adequate tissue coverage while maintaining flexibility. It is generally used on body areas where cosmesis is less of a priority compared to the face, which would require a full thickness graft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Full thickness skin graft: This graft involves both the epidermis and the entire dermis and is typically used for areas requiring greater cosmetic outcomes, such as the face. It is not generally used for large wounds with healthy granulation tissue, as STSG would suffice and cover larger areas with a better healing outcome.

 

Option C.  VAC dressing: Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing is used for non-healing or chronic wounds that require additional stimulation for granulation tissue formation and wound contraction. It is not needed when the wound already has healthy granulation tissue and is progressing well in healing.

 

Option D.  Flap: A flap is used when there is a need for bulk tissue to cover a deep or complex wound that involves structures like bone, tendons, or joints. Since the wound described has healthy granulation tissue and is not deep, a flap is unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Split thickness skin grafts are the best choice for covering large, healthy granulating wounds, particularly in areas where cosmesis is not the primary concern.

questions.text: A 6-day old child presents with bilious vomiting with double bubble sign on X-ray. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duodenal atresia

 

A 6-day-old neonate presenting with bilious vomiting and a "double bubble" sign on X-ray is indicative of duodenal atresia. The "double bubble" sign refers to the presence of two distinct air bubbles on the X-ray: one in the stomach and one in the proximal duodenum, separated by an obstruction, which is characteristic of duodenal atresia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infantile pyloric stenosis: This is incorrect because infantile pyloric stenosis typically presents after four weeks of age, not in a neonate. Additionally, the vomiting in pyloric stenosis is non-bilious, and the X-ray would show a single bubble due to stomach distention.

 

Option C. Jejunal atresia: This is incorrect because jejunal atresia presents with a "triple bubble" sign on X-ray.

 

Option D. Ileal atresia: This is incorrect because ileal atresia usually presents with multiple dilated loops of the intestine on X-ray, not a double bubble sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Duodenal atresia is diagnosed in neonates presenting with bilious vomiting and a double bubble sign on X-ray, indicating obstruction between the stomach and the proximal duodenum.

questions.text: A child is having fecal discharge from the umbilicus. What is the abnormality? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Patent vitello-intestinal duct

 

The patent vitello-intestinal duct, also known as a patent omphalomesenteric duct, is an abnormality where the duct that normally connects the yolk sac to the midgut during fetal development fails to close. This duct connects the ileum to the future umbilicus, and if it remains completely patent, it can lead to fecal discharge from the umbilicus, as seen in this case.

 

The persistence of the entire duct results in a direct communication between the ileum and the umbilicus, which can cause fecal matter to be discharged through the umbilicus. This condition is also referred to as an enterocutaneous fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalo-mesenteric cyst: This condition occurs when only a part of the vitello-intestinal duct remains patent in the middle, leading to a cystic swelling along the tract of the former duct. It does not cause fecal discharge from the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Remnant urachus: The urachus is a remnant of the fetal connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. A patent urachus would result in urine discharge from the umbilicus, not fecal discharge.

 

Option D. Omphalocele:  Presents with abdominal wall defect with herniation of intestines covered by peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecal discharge from the umbilicus in a child is indicative of a patent vitello-intestinal duct, which involves the persistence of the fetal duct connecting the ileum to the umbilicus.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

 

Gallbladder polyps are growths that emerge from the lining of the gallbladder. Those that are smaller than 10 mm are generally considered less likely to be cancerous. The risk of cancer increases with the size of the polyp, especially if it is larger than 10 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porcelain gallbladder: This condition is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall. It has been associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This is a chronic biliary disease marked by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. People with primary sclerosing cholangitis have an elevated risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and to a lesser extent, gallbladder cancer, especially if they develop gallbladder polyps.

 

Option D. Gallstone >3 cm: Large gallstones, especially those larger than 3 cm, have been linked with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired with its corresponding classification or criteria system? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Achalasia – LA classification

 

Achalasia is classified using the Chicago classification based on high-resolution manometry findings, not the LA classification. 

 

The Chicago classification divides achalasia into three types: 

 

  • Type I (classic achalasia with minimal esophageal pressurization), 
  • Type II (with panesophageal pressurization), and 
  • Type III (spastic achalasia with premature contractions). 

 

The LA (Los Angeles) classification is actually used for grading the severity of reflux esophagitis seen on endoscopy, grading from A to D based on the extent of mucosal breaks. This makes the pairing of Achalasia with LA classification incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic pancreatitis – Manheim score: Correctly paired. The Manheim score is a multifactorial scoring system used to assess the severity of chronic pancreatitis, incorporating clinical, laboratory, and imaging parameters.

 

Option C. Colonoscopy – Boston score: Correctly paired. The Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BBPS) is used to assess the quality of bowel preparation during colonoscopy, scoring each colon segment from 0-3 based on visualization quality.

 

Option D. Parathyroid resection – Miami criteria: Correctly paired. The Miami criteria are used intraoperatively during parathyroidectomy, where a >50% drop in PTH levels within 10 minutes after adenoma removal confirms successful surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia is classified using the Chicago classification (not LA classification); LA classification is used for grading reflux esophagitis on endoscopy.

choices.text: Improper dressing of an open chest wound can lead to tension pneumothorax
Simple pneumothorax can never become tension pneumothorax
It can commonly occur after mechanical ventilation with PEEP
Severe chest trauma with rib fractures can lead to it

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about tension pneumothorax? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simple pneumothorax can never become tension pneumothorax

 

Simple pneumothorax can indeed progress to tension pneumothorax if the tear in the pleura develops a one-way valve mechanism, allowing air to enter but not escape from the pleural space. This progression occurs when the pleural defect acts as a flap valve during respiratory cycles, trapping air with each breath and progressively increasing intrapleural pressure. The statement that simple pneumothorax "can never become" tension pneumothorax is false, as this conversion is a well-recognized complication that requires vigilant monitoring of patients with simple pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Improper dressing of an open chest wound can lead to tension pneumothorax: This statement is correct. Complete occlusion of an open pneumothorax (sucking chest wound) without allowing air to escape can convert it to tension pneumothorax. This is why three-sided occlusive dressings are recommended.

 

Option C. It can commonly occur after mechanical ventilation with PEEP: This statement is correct. Positive pressure ventilation, especially with PEEP, can rupture emphysematous bullae or cause barotrauma, leading to tension pneumothorax, particularly in patients with COPD or ARDS.

 

Option D. Severe chest trauma with rib fractures can lead to it: This statement is correct. Fractured rib ends can lacerate the visceral pleura, and the torn pleural edges can create a one-way valve mechanism resulting in tension pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple pneumothorax can progress to tension pneumothorax when a one-way valve mechanism develops at the pleural tear site, making continuous monitoring essential.

questions.text: A male bartender, following a fight was brought to the emergency with respiratory distress. On clinical evaluation, the breath sounds were absent with increased resonance on right side, and tracheal deviation on the left side was noted. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Traumatic Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features point to traumatic pneumothorax:

 

  • History of trauma (fight)
  • Respiratory distress
  • Absent breath sounds on one side (indicates collapsed lung)
  • Tracheal deviation to opposite side

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collapse of lung: Incorrect as collapse is a consequence of pneumothorax, not the primary diagnosis. Additionally, isolated collapse without pneumothorax doesn't cause increased resonance

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: Incorrect as pleural effusion develops gradually, gives dull percussion note and doesn't typically cause tracheal deviation unless massive

 

Option D. Consolidation of lung: Incorrect as consolidation shows increased vocal resonance, bronchial breathing and doesn't cause tracheal deviation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Traumatic pneumothorax presents with respiratory distress, absent breath sounds on affected side and possible tracheal deviation after trauma.

questions.text: Identify the device used in surgery: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Verees needle

 

The device shown in the image is a Verees needle, which is commonly used for establishing pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. The Verees needle is a spring-loaded needle with a blunt tip that retracts when it punctures the peritoneum, thereby reducing the risk of injury to internal organs. It is used to introduce carbon dioxide (CO2) gas into the peritoneal cavity, creating a working space for laparoscopic instruments.

 

CO2 is preferred for creating pneumoperitoneum because it is non-combustible and the risk of air embolism is low due to its rapid excretion from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural catheter:

 

 

Option C. Optical trocar:

 

 

Option D. Spinal needle:   

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Verees needle is a specialized instrument used to safely establish pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries by introducing CO2 into the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is/are true about Crohn’s disease, in contrast to ulcerative colitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

  • Perianal fistulae: Crohn’s disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses, and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease. This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohn’s disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohn’s disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohn’s disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohn’s disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crohn’s disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

questions.text: Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. In the proximal calf

 

Explanation:

 

Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located in the proximal calf region. It is one of the important named perforator veins that forms a direct communication between the superficial and deep venous systems. Specifically, Boyd's perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the deep veins (posterior tibial vein) at the level of the proximal calf. This perforator is clinically significant in patients with chronic venous insufficiency as incompetence in this perforator can contribute to varicose veins and venous hypertension.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. In the proximal thigh: This location is typically associated with Hunterian perforators, not Boyd's.
  • Option B. In the distal thigh: Dodd’s perforators are typically described in this location.
  • Option D. In the distal calf: This location is associated with Cockett's perforators (ankle perforators), which connect the posterior arch vein with the posterior tibial vein.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Boyd's perforator is located in the proximal calf, serving as an important communication between the great saphenous vein and deep posterior tibial vein. Its incompetence plays a significant role in the development of venous hypertension and varicose veins.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the urologist with complaints of abdominal pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. Upon examination, the physician noted tenderness in the lower abdomen and a palpable mass in the right flank area. Further evaluation revealed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelviureteric junction obstruction

 

The clinical scenario and the imaging indicate a likely diagnosis of pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction.

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition where there is a blockage at the point where the renal pelvis meets the ureter.
  • This blockage can lead to hydronephrosis, which is the swelling of a kidney due to a buildup of urine.
  • PUJ obstruction can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired. Symptoms can include flank pain, recurrent UTIs, and a palpable mass in severe cases.
  • The findings from imaging studies, showing hydronephrosis (dilated pelvicalyceal system), would support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Putty kidney: A putty kidney refers to a kidney that has been extensively damaged by tuberculosis. The kidney appears pale, and is often shrunk, firm, and non-functional. It would not typically cause a palpable mass and recurrent UTIs in the described manner of the patient in the question.

 

Option C. Staghorn calculus: Staghorn calculi are large kidney stones that occupy a large portion of the renal pelvis and its calyces, often having a shape resembling a stag's horn. They can lead to recurrent UTIs and can sometimes be palpable, especially if the kidney is also enlarged due to obstruction. However, the description in the question and the image seems more indicative of an obstruction at the PUJ rather than a staghorn calculus.

 

Option D. Cystic kidney: A cystic kidney, as the name suggests, is characterized by multiple cysts in the kidney. There are several diseases, like polycystic kidney disease, that can lead to cyst formation in kidneys. These cysts can sometimes cause pain, enlarged kidneys, and in some cases, recurrent UTIs. However, the specific findings from the imaging study mentioned in the question don't necessarily align with a simple cystic kidney diagnosis.

 

Given the findings mentioned in the question, a palpable mass in the right flank area, tenderness in the lower abdomen, and imaging results, Pelviureteric junction obstruction (Option A) is the most consistent and likely diagnosis for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pelviureteric junction obstruction is a condition causing blockage where the renal pelvis meets the ureter, leading to hydronephrosis and symptoms like flank pain and recurrent UTIs.
  • Imaging typically shows a dilated pelvicalyceal system.

choices.text: Bag mask ventilation with jaw thrust

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department following severe maxillofacial trauma sustained in a road traffic accident. The airway is compromised, and immediate intervention is required. What is the most appropriate immediate management? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroidotomy 

 

Cricothyroidotomy involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane to establish an emergency airway. It's the most appropriate immediate management in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway when orotracheal intubation is not feasible or contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy: Tracheostomy involves creating an opening in the trachea through the neck to establish an airway. While it's a definitive airway management technique, it's not the most appropriate immediate management in an emergency due to the time required and the need for specialized equipment.

 

Option B. Orotracheal intubation: Orotracheal intubation involves passing an endotracheal tube through the mouth into the trachea to secure the airway. It's a commonly performed procedure in emergency settings for airway management, but it may be challenging or contraindicated in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma.

 

Option D. Bag-mask ventilation with jaw thrust: Bag-mask ventilation involves manually delivering breaths using a bag and mask to ventilate the patient's lungs. While it can provide temporary oxygenation, it may not be sufficient for maintaining a patent airway in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway, cricothyroidotomy is the most appropriate immediate management to establish an emergency airway when orotracheal intubation is not feasible or contraindicated.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent surgery for rectal prolapse, and a postoperative image was obtained. Can you identify the procedure that was most likely performed on the patient from the given image below ? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiersch stitch

 

  • The postoperative image suggests the use of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse.
  • Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal.
  • It is now rarely done due to postoperative problems such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: A minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat internal hemorrhoids by repositioning prolapsed tissue back to its normal anatomical position with a circular stapling device. This procedure does not align with the provided image of Thiersch wiring.

 

Option B. Well's procedure: An abdominal procedure for rectal prolapse that involves repositioning and attaching the rectum to the sacrum using sutures, often reinforced with mesh. This technique does not correspond to the image provided, which clearly shows a perineal approach with wiring.

 

Option D. Altemeier repair: A perineal approach to resect and anastomose the prolapsed rectum. While Altemeier repair is a perineal procedure, it involves resection and anastomosis rather than the placement of a circumferential wire around the anus, as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiersch's procedure, involving the placement of a wire or tape around the anal canal, is used in managing rectal prolapse but is now infrequently performed due to associated complications such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

choices.text: A, B and D are correct

questions.text:
Which of these is/are included as a part of primary survey in trauma? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Endotracheal intubation
B. Chest X-ray
C. Plain CT
D. ICD insertion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and D are correct

 

The primary survey in trauma is a critical initial assessment conducted to identify and manage life-threatening conditions. It follows the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure). The focus is on stabilizing the patient, and only essential interventions are performed during this phase.

 

Option A. Endotracheal Intubation: This is part of airway management in an unstable trauma patient. If the airway is compromised or there is a risk of airway obstruction, endotracheal (ET) intubation is performed immediately to secure the airway.

 

Option B. Chest X-ray: Although a chest X-ray is considered an adjunct to the primary survey, it is often done bedside in the trauma room as part of the initial assessment of breathing and circulation. It is particularly useful for identifying conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or other thoracic injuries that require immediate attention.

 

Option D. ICD Insertion: Intercostal Drain (ICD) insertion is a bedside procedure that can be part of the primary survey if there is a massive pneumothorax or hemothorax. In cases of tension pneumothorax, an immediate needle decompression is performed, followed by ICD insertion, which is critical for patient survival.

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Plain CT: This is not included in the primary survey. CT scans are generally reserved for stable patients as they require the patient to be transported to the radiology department, which is not feasible or safe in an unstable trauma patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the primary survey of a trauma patient, life-saving interventions like ET intubation, bedside chest X-ray, and ICD insertion are performed to stabilize the patient. A CT scan is not part of this immediate assessment and is reserved for stable patients.

choices.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Echinococcus species is involved in Etiology

 

  • The given CT image shows a cyst in the liver is suggestive of hydatid disease with floating membrane sign.
  • Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly called the dog tapeworm.
  • MC site of hydatid cyst in human: liver (MC) followed by pulmonary hydatids (2nd MC)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgery is mandatory: Surgical treatment of hydatid cyst indicated when PAIR is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic: FNAC is contra-indicated as rupture of cyst may lead to spillage or anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. Angioembolization is the treatment of choice:  Angioembolization has no role in the management of hydatid cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hydatid disease of the liver, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by the formation of cysts that can be identified using imaging techniques like USG and CECT.
  •  The primary treatment approach includes medical management with albendazole followed by the PAIR procedure or surgery if PAIR is not feasible.
  •  FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient underwent hernia surgery and complained of a loss of sensations over the root of his penis during his postoperative recovery. The patient reported no prior history of genital trauma or surgery. Which of the following nerves would you suspect to be the cause of the patient's loss of sensation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilioinguinal nerve

 

The ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely nerve to be implicated in this scenario. It provides sensation to the skin over the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum, and can be injured during inguinal hernia repair surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Iliohypogastric nerve: The Iliohypogastric nerve carries sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve rarely causes sensory disturbances in the right iliac fossa due to the rich nerve supply from other sources. However, severing this nerve above the anterior superior iliac spine can lead to weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. Injury to this nerve can also occur following appendicectomy.

 

Option C. The genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve has a genital branch that provides sensation to the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the genital branch can cause loss of sensation in these areas.

 

The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament, but this is not relevant to the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh: The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh a sensory branch of the femoral nerve that supplies sensation to the anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee. Injury to this nerve can lead to loss of sensation in these areas, but is not related to the patient's loss of sensation in the root of the penis.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liposarcoma

 

Liposarcoma is the most commonly observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space. Liposarcomas are malignant tumors that arise from adipocytes and are most frequently located in the retroperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of muscle origin. While it can occur in various parts of the body, it is more commonly associated with pediatric populations in the neck.

 

Option C. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that tends to arise near large joints but can occur anywhere in the body.

 

Option D. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors. While they can occur in various parts of the body, including the retroperitoneum, they are not the most frequently observed tumor in this location. It's also important to note that when associated with certain genetic conditions like Neurofibromatosis type 1, they can be seen in multiple areas of the body, but they still don't surpass liposarcomas in frequency in the retroperitoneal space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins.
  • Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors.
  • The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors.
  • Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma.
  • Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. According to King's College Criteria for predicting mortality in Acute Liver Failure (ALF), which of the following is not included?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

 

Explanation: 

 

King's College Criteria are widely used to predict mortality in patients with acute liver failure and identify those who may require urgent liver transplantation.

 

Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy: According to the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol causes, a duration of jaundice before the onset of encephalopathy greater than 7 days (not less than 7 days) is one of the parameters that might indicate the need for liver transplantation. If the encephalopathy develops rapidly after the onset of jaundice (i.e., within 7 days), it suggests a more acute and potentially reversible cause, such as acute viral hepatitis, which might recover without transplantation.

 

Given the information, the incorrect parameter in the King's College criteria for transplantation, would be "Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy" (Option D).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age <10 years: Age is a factor in the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure. Children aged less than 10 years are considered at higher risk and this age group may be included in the criteria for transplantation.

 

Option B. PT >100s: Prothrombin time (PT) reflects the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors. A greatly prolonged PT (>100 seconds) is an indication of severe liver dysfunction and is one of the King's College Criteria for both paracetamol and non-paracetamol-induced liver failure as a potential requirement for liver transplantation.

 

Option C. Bilirubin >300 µmol/L: An elevated bilirubin level indicates significant liver dysfunction. A bilirubin level greater than 300 µmol/L is one of the King's College Criteria for non-paracetamol-induced liver failure and suggests that liver transplantation may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

King's College Criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure include specific parameters such as prolonged PT, elevated bilirubin, and specific age groups. The duration of jaundice before the development of encephalopathy is significant if it exceeds 7 days. Jaundice for less than 7 days is not a parameter for transplantation.

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak. This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut:  Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D. The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:


The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chef presented with complaints of leg pain and swelling. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with varicose veins. Further examination revealed the presence of skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C4

 

Explanation of the CEAP Classification:

 

The CEAP classification is a system used to categorize venous disease based on clinical, etiologic, anatomic, and pathophysiologic criteria. Here's a breakdown:

 

  • C: Clinical classification
  • E: Etiologic classification
  • A: Anatomic classification
  • P: Pathophysiologic classification

 

The "C" or clinical classification is divided as follows:

 

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
