  • C2: Varicose veins.
  • C3: Edema.
  • C4: Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into:
    • C4a: Pigmentation or eczema.
    • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
    • C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: Skin changes with healed ulceration.
  • C6: Skin changes with active ulceration.

 

In summary, the patient's symptoms of varicose veins combined with skin changes such as eczema and lipodermatosclerosis correspond to the C4 classification in the CEAP system.

questions.text: A patient suffered from an injury to right lower limb 3 days ago following which he was brought to hospital. The injury is as shown in the image. What would be the likely treatment in this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Debridement & hyperbaric oxygen

 

The given image shows gangrenous patches of the skin spread throughout the lower limb, with patchy erythema, likely indicative of necrotizing fasciitis. Extensive debridement with hyperbaric oxygen to hasten healing is recommended. Primary closure should not be done in the presence of necrotic tissue.

 

Debridement & hyperbaric oxygen:

 

  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Increases the oxygen concentration in the blood, which can help wounds heal more quickly and fight certain types of infections.
  • Suitability: For necrotizing fasciitis, prompt and aggressive debridement is crucial. After debridement, hyperbaric oxygen can be beneficial. It can suppress the growth of anaerobic bacteria, enhance white blood cell function, and improve tissue oxygenation – all of which are beneficial in treating necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Debridement & rotational advancement flap:

 

  • Debridement: Involves removing dead, damaged, or infected tissue to facilitate healing.
  • Rotational advancement flap: Involves moving nearby healthy skin and tissue to cover a wound.
  • Suitability: While debridement is crucial for necrotizing fasciitis, a rotational flap might not be the best immediate solution, especially if there's extensive tissue damage or ongoing infection. The primary focus should be on controlling the infection.

 

Option B. Debridement & primary closure:

 

  • Primary closure: Means directly suturing or closing the wound after debridement.
  • Suitability: In the case of necrotizing fasciitis, primary closure is not recommended initially. It's essential to ensure that all necrotic tissue is removed and the infection is under control before thinking about wound closure. Closing a wound with any lingering infection can lead to the infection being trapped and can worsen the patient's condition.

 

Option D. Amputation:

 

  • Amputation: Involves surgically removing a body part, typically an extremity.
  • Suitability: In some severe cases of necrotizing fasciitis, especially if the infection has rapidly progressed and threatens the patient's life, amputation might be a consideration. However, it's a last-resort treatment and would be considered only if other treatments fail and the limb is non-salvageable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For necrotizing fasciitis, the initial treatment should include extensive debridement and hyperbaric oxygen therapy to control the infection and promote healing.

choices.text: USG is nearly 100% sensitive to detect IHPS
It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone
Common metabolic condition seen is Hypokalemic alkalosis

questions.text: In Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) which of these would not be seen? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone

 

Among the given options, the statement "C. It is due to hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles alone" is the one that would not be seen in a case of Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

 

Which makes it the right answer to the question asking which wouldn't be seen in IHPS. IHPS is caused by hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, not the longitudinal muscles. This hypertrophy leads to an obstruction at the gastric outlet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It presents with non-bilious vomiting: This statement is correct. IHPS typically presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. This is because the pyloric stenosis obstructs the gastric outlet, but it is located before the bile duct entry into the duodenum. Therefore, vomitus will not contain bile.

 

Option B. USG is nearly 100% sensitive to detect IHPS: While ultrasonography (USG) is a highly sensitive and commonly used modality for the diagnosis of IHPS, stating that it is nearly "100% sensitive" may be an overstatement. However, for the purpose of the question, it is understood that USG is the preferred and very reliable method of diagnosis.

 

Option D. Common metabolic condition seen is Hypokalemic alkalosis: This statement is correct. Prolonged vomiting due to IHPS leads to the loss of gastric acid. This results in a metabolic alkalosis. The kidneys compensate for this by excreting more potassium in the urine, leading to hypokalemia. Hence, the condition termed "hypokalemic alkalosis" is a common metabolic disturbance in IHPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) involves hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, leading to gastric outlet obstruction and presenting with non-bilious vomiting. It is commonly diagnosed via highly sensitive ultrasonography, and the associated metabolic disturbance is hypokalemic alkalosis.

choices.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.
Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

 

Laparoscopic surgeries have become popular as they result in lesser post-operative pain, are cosmetically better, and result in an earlier return to normal physiological function (Options A, B, and C). Patients are discharged from the hospital earlier, with a lower incidence of complications, as compared to open surgeries. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer, as it is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

This statement is incorrect. Laparoscopic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays compared to traditional open surgery. Patients typically spend less time in the hospital and recover faster, which is one of the key advantages of this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain: Smaller incisions and less tissue trauma typically result in less post-operative pain compared to traditional open surgery.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions: This is an advantage of laparoscopic surgery. The smaller incisions are not only cosmetically appealing but also result in reduced scarring and a lower risk of wound infections.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function: Patients often recover more quickly and can resume their normal activities sooner due to the minimally invasive nature of the procedure.

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma

 

The image shown is of Whipple’s procedure, which can be done for distal cholangiocarcinoma.

 

  • Whipple's procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, is a complex surgical procedure that involves removing the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the common bile duct, the gallbladder, and sometimes a portion of the stomach.
  • This procedure is typically performed to treat cancer of the pancreas, duodenum, or the ampulla of Vater

 

Distal cholangiocarcinoma is cancer that occurs in the bile ducts, typically in the lower part of the bile duct near the pancreas. The procedure referred to in the question is often associated with the surgical management of distal cholangiocarcinoma. It involves a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy), which is a complex surgical procedure to remove the affected part of the bile duct, pancreas, and small intestine, and then reconstruct the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advanced gastric carcinoma: The management of advanced gastric carcinoma typically involves various approaches, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Surgical procedures such as gastrectomy or lymphadenectomy may be performed depending on the stage and location of the tumor.

 

Option B. Gallbladder carcinoma: Gallbladder carcinoma may be treated with surgical resection, often involving cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) and potentially more extensive procedures if the cancer has spread. However, the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to gallbladder carcinoma.

 

Option D. Chronic calcific pancreatitis: Chronic calcific pancreatitis may require surgical intervention in certain cases, but the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to this condition. Surgical options for chronic pancreatitis may include drainage procedures or resection of the affected pancreatic tissue.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The procedure mentioned in the question, which is often performed to manage distal cholangiocarcinoma, is a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy).

questions.text: A patient with oral cancer as shown. What is the T stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T4a

 

Based on TNM staging for oral cancer:

 

  • Invasion of the floor of the mouth is considered T4a as per AJCC staging
  • Tumor invading floor of mouth indicates local invasion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2:

 

  • T2 represents tumor 2-4 cm without deep invasion
  • Does not account for floor-of-mouth involvement

 

Option B. T3:

 

  • T3 represents tumor >4 cm without deep invasion
  • Does not account for local invasion

 

Option D. T4b:

 

  • Represents very advanced local disease
  • Involves masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base
  • Involves encasement of internal carotid artery
  • These structures not involved in this case

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Invasion of floor of mouth in oral cancer represents T4a disease, indicating moderately advanced but resectable local disease.
